title: Will the yield curve for 2-year and 10-year U.S. Treasuries invert before 2019?
preds: Ouch, I waited too long before ret8urning to forecast.
Too late in the year now

Considering the current fed policy stance of continually raising rates, and the fact that the economy is still somewhat strong, I expect credit activity to be fairly robust over the next several months.
As much as I dislike 0% and 100% forecasts, an inversion is next to impossible to imagine happening at this point.
2y yield is 2.56% and 10y yield is 2.77%. It seems unlikely to occur in the remaining 2 trading days
Hard to imagine it happening at this point.
The spread as of the 26th of December is 0.2%, so it seems very unlikely for the inversion to occur this year
Too soon. It will, but not within a week. Current trend is weakly divergent.
Jerome Powell is behaving just like previous Fed Chairs. The data dependency and lack of real world connectiveness will cause him to overshoot.
Spread is still at 0.16%, and there are only a few days left

On 12/6/18 the spread between the 2 and 10 year is only 13 bps, which half of what it was on my last forecast. The CME Fedwatch website predicts Fed rate movements based on the futures market. Right, now it places a 74% probability that the Fed will raise rates at its December 18-19 meeting by 25 bps (https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html). 
Since this probability is well known and considered by bond investors, I’ll say that the remaining 24% uncertainty is not already baked into the current 2 year rate and that there should only be a 6.5 basis point (25 bps increase x 26% of uncertainty) increase in the 2 year rate. If that happens, the 2 year adjusts accordingly, and the 10 year rate remains unchanged, the spread reduced to 6.5 bps. At this point, I’ll assume a base rate of 0% probability of inversion. 
Theoretically, the yield curve should never invert because longer term investors demand a term premium. So, as the 2 year rate increases, the 10 year should increase by and unknown amount. Though, the term premium, as determined by the current spread is very small. In addition, an inversion is a very rare occurrence (https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/T10Y2Y). My probability remains 0% at this point. 
Current economic reports also lead bond investors to draw conclusions about rates in the future which can have a positive or negative effect on longer term yields. I don’t claim to have any more incite about upcoming economic reports than anyone else, but we have to consider the short window before the question concludes. For instance, after the Fed announces its decision to raise rates (or to leave it unchanged or decrease), there are only 6 days (excluding holidays) until the question concludes. Thus, reducing the probability of inversion. So, I’ll remain at 0% probability 
Another thing to consider is that foreign countries are also investors in US debt markets. A few major economies have extremely low or negative rates and have found US debt to be more attractive from both yield and creditworthiness perspectives. Additional buying of US debt from these countries would put downward pressure on US yields. Since this situation has persisted for quite some time and would likely affect both the 2 and 10 year rates, I believe that if this assessment is correct the affects will have no further downward pressure on rates unless those rates were to decrease. I think this is very unlikely considering their central bank agendas. In addition, any rate increases in those countries would have upward pressure on rates, but that is very unlikely between now and the end of the question. I’m not changing my probability because of this unless something significant happens. 
On the other hand, because we are starting from such a historically small spread, any negative news or a continued bearish sentiment in equity markets could cause the 10 year rate to decrease and reduce the spread at any time between now and the end of the question.

Five days is simply not enough time for the yield curve, which rarely if every inverts, to do so unless a recession is going to blindside everyone.  But consumer confidence remains high, and the excesses that usually lead to a recession, such as excess corporate and household capital spending and operating leverage, are not present in the U.S. economy.
Invert curve between 2 year and 10 year US Treasuries will happen Q1 2019 and the crisis of global economy will happen in Q4 2019 or Q1 2020.
The fed meeting is evidence that rate hikes are slowing.

If you follow the yield curve, you will see it is headed to invert around Q1 - Q2 of 2019. There is a reasonable chance it will invert in 2018 December data, but not much. See the curve (red) overlapping housing starts (blue, which I always add for context) to see the coming inversion of the red curve dipping below 0. https://fred.stlouisfed.org/graph/fredgraph.png?g=mtTW
Fed made move, more expected, but curve move running out of time. It will happen during 1Q19.
while we're getting closer to inversion on the 2s10s I don't the at the current rate of narrowing we'll get there by year end.

GreekFire23 @GreekFire23
Front end rates have been controlled by man for 105 years. Long end rates have been controlled by economic fundamentals since inception. This is why curves invert.
8:14 AM - 17 Dec 2018
Lowering to 50% after the Fed’s last meeting in 2018.

Spread tightened 4 basis points on the news that the Fed will raise rates one more time in 2018. I still think the probability of an inversion is low since traders are typically unwilling to make big bets towards the end of the year.
Even with the .03 drop this week, it doesn't seem to be dropping at a rate quick enough to happen within the year

Yield curve rarely, if ever, gives "false positives", inverting when no recession is in sight.  Since I do not believe a recession is coming, I'll go out on a limb and use zero as my probability.  @statwoman
https://www.gjopen.com/questions/1035-will-the-yield-curve-for-2-year-and-10-year-u-s-treasuries-invert-before-2019
Little time remaining, most volatility has been in equity.  Suspect future very bad news to be tied to sufficiently large crimes like Krispy Kreme of yore.
The spread has widened, if only slightly. (Current spread 0.17)
It went up to 0.18 today. With 9 trading days, it's ~1% chance.
5 point increase last week plus not change today bodes well for not inverting before 2019.
Dropping back down to 67% in what I anticipate might be the beginning of a slide back down to the lower end of the spectrum.
The gap is wide right now, so I have reduced my confidence level accordingly.
the gap between 2 & 10 yr treasuries has widened a bit . . .
The gap is currently wide before the end date which is closing in relentlessly. The yield curve will invert and soon, but maybe not in the next couple of weeks.
Updating because of an increase in the spread and the diminishing time remaining. (Current spread of 0.16)
Updating, spread has stabilized, therefore adjusting probability down.

There is very little time until Jan 1 and currently the gap is wide enough to make closing it by the time frame of this question hard. Could happen, but less likely than it looked like a couple of weeks ago.

Took 2016 to present data, there is a current 0.16 differential. I then counted the number of times there was a drop of 0.16 in the subsequent 11 trading days. Turns out that 0.16 is pretty high for this yield curve. It happened 30/470 days or 57/470 times. I'm coming back down to 5% of the time.
Gap is widening, the 3 and 5 year yields are no longer inverted.. starting to look like a reversal.
The gap has widened instead of closing a reversal of recent trends.
Fed guidance after Dec meeting will allow curve to steepen
Current 2-10 tsy spread is 16 bps and with another Fed hike likely in December, the yield curve should continue to flatten and potentially invert.
The yield curve has inverted at the short end of the curve
Based on the trend in the 2yr and 10 yr rates, inversion is close, but there are only 2 weeks left in the year.

If you take from January 1, 2016 to now, the yield has dropped -0.11 or more in 13 trading days in just 7% of cases. Add in the general slow decline of this yield and the Fed still doing easing, it's probably less. But, the sudden recent drop does cause me a little concern, so I'll come up to 10%.

I said in my last post that "If it (the 10-2 Diff) falls by -.04 this week then it will be on course to invert before Jan-01." I am beginning to feel that the inversion may happen within 2018, but I feel it will be close. Yesterday's fall of -.02, though not as bad as last weeks falls of -.06 & -.04, still doesn't bode well.
Raising the forecast back up to 88%.
it contracted 20 bps over last week or so, so it could get there.

The 2-10 is close to inverting, and it would probably just take the Fed raising rates in combination with poor economics news to make it invert.  I think that is possible but not likely, but because it is so close I'm giving it a bit less that 50% chance

Foreign investors spurn U.S. Treasuries as curve threatens to invert
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-bonds-foreigners/foreign-investors-spurn-u-s-treasuries-as-curve-threatens-to-invert-idUSKBN1OA0J6?il=0

looking back over the data, I see that between the in Nov the difference between the 2-year and the 10-year fell by .15, which is greater than what remains of the difference (.13), and just in this week has already fallen by .02. I'm still skeptical it will fully invert before Jan-1 but it is looking more that way than it was before. If it falls by -.04 this week then it will be on course to invert before Jan-01.

it's moving faster than i'd expected. 
(as i get older, this is true of more and more things.)

I’m lowering to 75%.  The spread seems to be enlarging a little, which is why I’m lowering a bit.  But I think the overall environment is still too uncertain to lower the forecast much more than a small amount right now.

When you do a survey of articles and commentary related to yield curve inversion, you find that the vast majority of what has been written is about what an inverted yield curve might portend.  And the conventional wisdom is that it portends a recession.  And right now, for instance, the Internet is awash in opinion pieces about whether last week’s belly-of-the-curve inversion points to a recession.
I believe a recession will hit by 2020.
Although the yield curve is flattening, and it only has to invert for one day, there are not many days left for it to happen.

Looking into the actual difference between the yields on the 2 and 10 year bonds is getting REALLY  close (only a diff of 1.2 as of yesterday). It only needs to happen for a day BUT it also needs to happen in the next 24 Days. Given the rate it has been falling this year, and the rate it has been falling historically. I think it almost certainly will happen, but I don't think it will happen within 2018.
I am sticking with 88% for now.

Updating for the passage of time.
Increasing my probability of an inversion to 88%.
Finance industry started seasonal holiday early

Updating due to new information and passage of time:
1) rate hikes by the Fed might go ahead slower than anticipated. This is expected to increase or at least not decrease inflation supporting the long end of the curve. Additionally it should depress the short end of the curve, so make inversion less likely. 
2) However, in the 18 business days since my last forecast on 8th November, the spread decreased by 0.15 percentage points to 0.11 percent, or 0.0083 percentage points per day. This rate has accelerated, and since there are 18 business days to the question closing, it has become more likely that the curve inverts, even if only for a short time due to volatility.
The spread has been shrinking for a while now still i think chances on inversion are low but not very low because of the ongoing trade conflicts and the chances of an overheating of US economy.
3 yr has inverted and that’s sooner than expected

Expected rises in Fed Funds rate and a levelling off of economic activity, plus record Treasury funding in the short end of the market will encourage a flat then inverted curve between 2 year and 10 year TN’s. The curve from 10 year notes to 30 year bonds may be much slower in flattening and may not invert.
I do believe that the yield curve will continue to flatten, but will not invert until 2019.
Adjusting my number up quite a bit.  I thought yield curve inversion prior to 2019 was highly unlikely, but it has moved pretty close recently.

I made a mistake in my last forecast. I made a forecast considering what would be the price at the end of the year, but if the curve inverts and then goes normal, in my forecast it would be a "no". So I updated with the new simulated results.

@redsparrow at www.reuters.com
The 2 to 5 yield curve inverted today and  adjusting forecast to take account of the possibility that the due to market volatility the 5 year/10 year could follow
Chance of a 2019 recession small;  economy still relatively robust; need to keep eye on leveraged loans and non investment grade credit assets for signs of deterioration.
Forgot to actually change the prediction!

Out of curiosity, I went to the Fed's yield curve page and downloaded the data. If you go with a straight historical POV of how many times the difference has moved this much over the number of trading days, it's something like 15% probability. But, if you look at the chart, there are clearly two types of inversion, quick and slow. This is the slow type, like the one in December 1999. It hung around for months in the .20-.05 range. And we have had the same, monthly averages starting July 2018 are: .2823, .2534, .2363, .2913, and .258. Will it make a big move downward in December? It's possible, but it's much less that the historical 15%. I'll come up to 5%, but I don't think it is more than a 1 in 20 chance.
Increasing odds now that only 15bps gap between 2-10. Any sort of panic filled day could cause an inversion.

There are 27 days until the end of this question and 15 bps to invert. Using the data from 2000 to 2018 I calculated 18% chance of inverting using a parametric method, with the standard deviation and using a normal distribution, and 13% with a nonparametric method using historical returns.
the 3 and 5 year bonds just inverted. But I don't think the 2/10 will do it before Jan 1.
On December 3 2018 the yield curve delta is 0.15. At current trends the yield curve will invert in 2 weeks, and before the predicted end date of this forecast.
Less than a month left and would require a very adverse market event to raise the 2-year that much
I am raising my forecast to 7% based on end-of-the-week data and a few things I gleaned over the weekend.

Short of some dramatic news that will spook the bond market - I don't see how the yields will be inverted with 4 weeks left to go in the year. I think 2 year will stabilize around 2.8% for the rest of the year and 10 years will remain around the 3% mark.
Going back up to 5% due to the perturbations following the release of the Fed's November minutes.
Lowering to 4% based on Chairman Powell's comments yesterday and the market reaction.

The general LT term trend is about 6bps a month, charicterised by small movements down followed by a couple of larger moves up. WIth only a month to go it is unlikely to make the 22bps downwards move without a clear catalyst. Given Fed commentary yesterday, upward pressure on the 2 is unlikely to materialise, meaning very low probability of inversion this year.
Recent comments by Fed indicate slowing in rate rise for 2019, if so, no good reason for 2/10 inversion.
Lowering probability on the basis of analysis at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/792676, thank you, @redsparrow.
Chairman Powell's comments today about rates are "just below" estimates of neutral.
It would require a big shock to the economy for this to happen, and I think any shock would asymmetrically be in the opposite direction of inversion.

Someone -- @redsparrow? @dsarin? please help me understand how this might affect the curve inversion likelihood over time: https://www.fxstreet.com/news/breaking-news-usd-falls-sharply-as-feds-powell-says-policy-rate-is-just-below-estimates-of-neutral-201811281706
With a month left, I highly doubt it based on previous analysis
I am changing my forecast to a 5% chance of inverting for at least one day before the year's end.  Two factors lead me to lower my forecast.

Increasing likelihood slightly as I am more confident that the Fed will raise the interest rate again in December. Reason: falling gas prices, some other commodities, and the tanking stock market (which tends to hurt investment, other spending)  are placing a damper on inflation, giving the Fed more wiggle room. In addition, the Fed needs the power to drop rates to zero if need be when the next recession hits. This might arrive soon, so better to prepare now.
Too soon.  It will invert sometime in 2019, though.

According to a friend who wishes to remain anonymous, "We are seeing a lot of market indicators flashing red now. The attendant flight to safety, and a Fed December rate hike might just be enough to invert the yield curve between the UST 2 year and 10 year." So it looks like this question depends upon whether the Fed does, indeed, hike the rate again in December. @Shuper24 cites an Oct. 2017 article on this issue here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/789885. Fed calendar says the decision is slated for Dec. 18 - 19.  https://www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/2018-december.htm If yes, does this give enough time to invert? Raising probability slightly.

Current spread 23 bps, the day of Lehman the spread contracted by 18 bp, so unlikely a higher contagion this time out of fear. The other factor would be a rise in inflationary expectations in the remaining month, which I see unlikely
it will invert, but not until Q1 2019

The most analysts on Bloomberg TV say, that always in the past a recession came, when the yield curve inverted. Since Greenspan period, the FED is programmed to avoid any recession. Several times a day Bloomberg asks different financial experts of Investors, like Blackrock, UBS, Allianz, what the opinion of their institutions are about changes of interest rates by FED. Nearly all say the interest rates will be increased in small steps by FED until 2019 until the neutral interest rate is achieved, 3% till 4%. The USA is late in Boom Bast cycle. The most Representatives expecting recession by end 2019 and beginning of 2020. The majority expecting a very flat inversion of yield curve by 2019 till 2020. The representatives of financial institutions signaling what their possible actions of financial markets are. These institutions move the markets: Blackrock has for example a portfolio of about 6000 Billion US $ or so.
Conclusion: Inversion of yield curve will come with 60% probability or so in 2019 or later but with high probability not in 2018.
It appears as though the yields are moving in tandem. It also seems as though there is too much ground to make up for the yield to invert should the yields begin to converge.
The 2-10 curve will invert prior to year end if the market is expecting two rate increases between now and Feb 15, 2019.
I dont know enough to answer this.  Going with the crowd on this!
They can’t lower interest rate at this point.

The yields on the 2 and 10 yr are, 2.79 and 3.05 as of 11/20/18. If the FED decides to increase the rate by 25bps in December I foresee the increase impacting all yields, maybe not evenly but enough that the 10yr will still be elevated vs the 2yr.
I am going to make an initial forecast of 11.3% that it will invert (and I'm disappointed the input form doesn't seem to take decimals).

With the synchronized upward movement of rates following the most recent Fed action in September, the 2/10 spread has held relatively firm.  The expected size of the December move (0.25%) combined with solid earnings, earnings growth, employment, and inflation measures all work against the scenario which would see a potential rate inversion in the next 45 days - a pullback in the markets that approaches recession levels.   3% is given.  The increased levels of volatility in October lower this forecast, as relative valuations in the market are more reasonable, and the volatility makes an argument for delaying another rate increase by the Fed, if anything.  (Rather than making the case for faster rate increases.)

With just under six weeks left in the year, it does not seem that there's enough market pressures to lead to the inversing of the 10-year and 2-year Treasury bond yields before the end of the year.  The likelihood of the inversion happening DURING 2019 is very high, but it is not likely to happen before March given current market trajectories.
It will invert, but not before 2019.

Given the rising bank rates, the short-end of the curve has been rising, and has a good chance to rise further before 2019. The yield curve flattening since early this year has been driven by higher two-year rates, reflecting that sort of rise in the expected Fed funds rate two years later. However, the long end of the curve is not rising at the same magnitude as the short rate, partly due to a large demand coming from pension, as pension de-risk by moving to bonds from equity. The Treasuries were also getting sold off this year amid surging issuance, driven by the US tax cut and an increase in fiscal spending. Given the combination of the factors above, there is a good chance that the yield curve may invert again this year, but on a temporarily basis.

the current spread is 25 bps and the average bps contraction in spread is 2.9 per month YTD and about 3-4bps per month since 2014 when the spreads peaked. At the end of 2014 the spread did accelerate and contract at 15.7 bps per month. In order to get to negative by year end with 1.6 months left spreads would have to contract at the end of 2014 velocity, which to me could only happen if there was great weakness in the economic outlook and a higher confidence in a near term recession, which I put at 1-5% percent through year end.

Only one more fed decision before this.. even with increase in rates, doubt it will invert.. although it is getting dangerously close. Good article here (although little outdated) https://www.stlouisfed.org/on-the-economy/2017/october/increases-fed-funds-rate-impact-other-interest-rates

The 2 year rate is likely to move up slightly as time moves us along the path of fed increases and the market becomes convinced of the fed's resolve. A crash in the stock market could easily drive cause 10 year yields to be bid down below the 2 year.  I give this possibility a 20% chance of happening before the end of 2018.
Not in the next 6 weeks. Spread is now about 24 basis points. If a sudden crisis, short term rates will probably plummet

The yield curve will not invert, as the economy is still in an upswing.  Additionally, the US economy is showing signs of increased inflation, which will keep the 2 year rate below the 10-year rate for now
The Fed is likely to continue raising the fed fund rate to accommodate the faster economic growth and accelerating inflation.
Though they are beginning to invert, the idea that they will end up inverting in this year seems unlikely
Following @redsparrow for your base rate evidence cited here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/789179
I do not believe that the yield curve will invert before 2019.
World instability and the effect of tariffs
Economy is doing pretty well, would need a scare to drive down longer term rates while also getting additional hikes from the Fed.

Clearly my first prediction was a big overestimation. The base rates are quite low as evidenced by Fed's own data: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/T10Y2Y, even on the daily series. Given that, and the small amount of time left, i'll put the odds at 1%.

Though, the time premium, as determined by the current spread is very small. In addition, an inversion is a very rare occurrence (https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/T10Y2Y). My probability remains 0% at this point.

I don’t claim to have any more incite about upcoming economic reports than anyone else, but we have to consider the short window before the question concludes. For instance, after the Fed announces its decision to raise rates (or to leave it unchanged or decrease), there are only 6 days (excluding holidays) until the question concludes. Thus, reducing the probability of inversion. So, I’ll remain at 0% probability
Another thing to consider is that foreign countries are also investors in US debt markets. A few major economies have extremely low or negative rates and have found US debt to be more attractive from both yield and creditworthiness perspectives. Since this situation has persisted for quite some time and would likely affect both the 2 and 10 year rates, I believe that if this assessment is correct the affects will have no further downward pressure on rates unless those rates were to decrease. I think this is very unlikely considering their central bank agendas. In addition, any rate increases in those countries would have upward pressure on rates, but that is very unlikely between now and the end of the question. On the other hand, because we are starting from such a historically small spread, any negative news or a continued bearish sentiment in equity markets could cause the 10 year rate to decrease and reduce the spread at any time between now and the end of the question. 
For the final answer to remain at 0% seems foolish. I’ll add a somewhat arbitrary 10% points to my probability to account for the possibility of negative economic news or random exogenous event. For instance, heightened trade war threats or other negative geopolitical event. I’ll go with 10% for now.
The 10-2 slope had been tightening  for a while, but has stabilized since mid-year. Markets have already factored in the Fed rate hikes for rest of the year.
Reducing after having weathered the elections.

I find it likely that the curve inverts in 2019, but not very likely in 2018.  it would take a major collapse of the stock market for that to happen so soon.  Even if a geopolitical event breaks out, investors would likely rush to the 2yr and drive that yield lower along with the 10yr.  It will truly take an expected economic downturn over the next 3 months to invert the curve that soon.

While probability is not 0, it is likely low and in range of perhaps 3% to as high as 10%.  Fed is likely to raise Fed Funds rate in December and communicate that it plans additional increases in 2019.  Eventually, symptoms of consumer debt and weaker spending will percolate and 10-year could quickly revert to < 3.00%.  Compounded with any signs of weaker corporate growth, spending, and/or geopolitical complications, 10-year could further decrease and yield curve could briefly invert with 2-year currently ~ 2.90% and Fed intent on raising rates throughout 2019.  Again, highly unlikely to happen before 2019, but probability is not 0 either.

The ratio is creeping up, but unless something odd happens the curve won't flip until after 1 January.   One hesitates, of course, to suppose that nothing odd will happen.  Orange swans are everywhere these days.

The spread between the 2 and 10 year yield is somewhere between 20-30 recently. The chance of the Fed raising rate by 25 bps is not zero and it's possible the spread will even narrow more. However, with only limited amount of time left in 2018 and holiday season coming (i.e. typically less activities in the markets), I would think the inverted yield curve is more or less a tail risk.
With inflationary pressures building the bond market will start building up the inflation premium in the curve and push up the 10 year rate.
Economy strong.  I don't see the ten year tightening much from here until the end of the year.
I expect flattening, but I do not expect it to happen that fast.

There will only be one more Fed rate increase in December, which the market has already priced in.  Assuming the short end of the curve ends the year at or near 3%, rates on the long end of the curve would have to fall approximately 20 bps over the next 6 weeks.  While possible, it is not probable as the Fed continues to reduce their balance sheet reinvestment by $50B/month and debt issuance by the US govt is anticipated to increase.  An unforeseen economic or global event, while not likely, could lead to a risk off trade in the market, leading to an inverted yield curve, hence the 5% probability.

The current base case for rates in the United States is that rates will continue to rise through the remainder of the year, and the steepness of the curve to slowly decrease.  For the yield curve to invert before 2019, there would need to be a catalyst or potential catalyst that would cause investors to shift investment preferences rapidly to the longer end of the curve. The possibility of a recession in the next six months could be the catalyst that could cause the Fed to change policy and begin to ease rates which would make investors prefer to investment for longer terms at current rates possibly causing an inversion.  However, there are no signs of a recession in the short-term (i.e. 12 months)  Perception is reality though.  If the markets perceives a recession is likely to occur it would cause investors to start investing in longer duration assets farther out on the yield curve (which is needed to cause the longer end yields to fall).   Investors would need to perceive there is a potential for rates to remain flat or fall in a reasonable time frame in the future to make the herd rush toward the long end of the curve and cause an inversion.  I currently see no scenarios at this time that could occur in the next 60 days that would cause investors to believe a recession is imminent and for the Fed to change policy.
Fed QT and longer-term US govt bond issuance with reduced demand from markets like China and Japan likely to drive longer-term rates higher over the duration of 2018
Lack of Liquidity will force higher short term rates.

At this moment, the two rates are 25 basis points apart. According to Fed Funds futures, the short end is known with relatively high probability (75% probability of one more 25 basis point increase in Fed Funds and that is what the Fed is telegraphing, as well), which would take the 2-year yield up by almost that amount. It then wouldn't take much of a decline in the 10-year rate (a few basis points) to result in an inversion. I still think it is unlikely, but if the markets start to price in any significant probability of a recession in 2019, the 10-year could drop a few basis points, which would then result in a very slight inversion. I still think the most likely outcome is no inversion, but I give an inversion a higher probability than most forecasters, it appears.
only have 2 months left; yes, the fed will move rates up in december but the curve has slowed its flattening bias  and has been moving up in parallel shifts.

I believe we will see the 10 yr's rate acceleration keep pace with the 2 yr as we move towards the end of the year keeping the curve from inverting. But with the crazy volatility swings we've seen this year, who knows.  I still think the probability is still very low.

The long term economic outlook will remain too variable given the political results of the midterm and possible deals with China over the trade war.  This will prevent long term rates from going below short term rates until the long term outlook is clearer.  The short time frame of the question also points to a lower possibility of change from the status quo.
My understanding is that a yield curve has only inverted 2 or 3 times before and only once when comparing 2yr & 10yr bond rates. Some one correct me if I'm wrong.
No, Economic growth is very strong currently, but with the midterm election results, there will be enough uncertainty to keep the curve.
We're already in November.  I simply do not believe the curve will invert before 2019.
The gap is closing but not fast enough for the time frame of the question.
Slope is still positive currently.  Don't believe the difference in rates will change meaningfully before year end.

With one more Fed rate hike forecasted in 2018, it seems unlikely that the yield curve will invert in these final few weeks of the year. Fed activity in 2019 is much more likely to run the risk of a yield curve inversion.

A parallel shift upward is much more likely than an inversion in the 2 months remaining in the year. An inversion indicates broad confidence in an upcoming recession, this broad confidence does not exist.
Only two months to go left in the year.
only flattening at most due to the  US strong economy. The short term rate should not rise too high as the US economy may also constrainted by  the slow down in Europe and China

It would take a calamity or an unexpected event to cause the Fed to alter its gradual hiking cycle. It would be improbable but its is a possibility. The Treasury is ramping up bond issuance during the 4th quarter to meet its budget deficit. Increasing supply along with dwindling demand will put upward pressure on yields. The long end of the curve is more sensitive due to a smaller base of buyers.

There is a spread of 30bps with 55 days to go before the beginning of 2019. These levels are virtually on top of where they were one month ago, with the entire curve shifting up 4 and 13bps respectively between the 2 and 10yr last week.

There will need to be a large change in economic events to see a full inversion.  The question is also worded such that it has to happen before 2019, which means no later than close of business on Monday, Dec 31, 2018.
with only two months left to go, a dramatic shift in either bond rate would be required to cause an inversion. Would have to be some sort of black swan event.
The chance of a structural inverted curve is low if the Fed continues to telegraph decisions, however can it invert for a few days if there's an unexpected shock?  Sure.
I think the chance of a structurally inverted yield curve is low unless the Fed breaks with their current cautious and highly communicated approach.. that said, could it ON ANY GIVEN DAY?  possibly..

Seems rather unlikely. The best chance for this to occur would probably be if we see a sharp surprise to the downside in inflation data in the next couple of months, reversing upward pressure on long term rates. Will be important to keep an eye on CPI, PCE, PPI etc. The Fed will almost certainly hike in December as they do not like to shock the markets and prefer to telegraph their intentions. Even with a hike, a 25 bp rise in the overnight rate (1) would likely not move the 2 year rate that by the same amount (2) would still not force an inversion at today's yields even if the 2 year rate did move that much and (3) is likely already at least partially priced in by market participants.

The current short term rate is around 2.25%. 10 year rate is around 3% . The fed will either increase the short term rate by 25 basis point or keep it as it is. Based on that i don't see  it crossing 3% mark. Also, I am not seeing the 10 year rate going down to 2 to 2.5% either based on current economic conditions. Hence my forecast.

While the Fed has clearly stated that it will increase the Federal Funds Rate in the coming months, it is possible that the Fed votes to maintain the rate unchanged for their November meeting and increase it a few basis points for the December meeting. An increase of a few basis points before 2019 and sustained demand for longer term loans (both commercial and consumer) should be able to maintain the curve upward sloping at least for the next 6 months.

This link: https://www.gurufocus.com/yield_curve.php -- courtesy of @Jim2, shows that inversion has been a very reliable indicator of recessions, and it occurs well before the recession begins.   None of the excesses that normally lead to recessions are present in the U.S. economy.
